title: Netul Landing & the Netul River Trail
listingDescription: In 1805, Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, accompanied by their crew of explorers, paddled up a river that the local peoples called Netul, today called the Lewis and Clark River.Â On December 5, the expedition established their winter camp at a site on the riverbank that had been selected by Lewis.

images.credit: IMG_0139.JPG by Michael Cornelius is licensed under CC BY-SA 2.0
images.altText: Old dock posts rise from the waters of the river, golden colored trees line the banks
images.title: Netul River Trail
images.caption: The Netul River Trail

relatedParks.fullName: Lewis & Clark National Historic Trail
relatedParks.name: Lewis & Clark

relatedParks.fullName: Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lewis and Clark

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
bodyText:
History

In 1805, Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, accompanied by their crew of explorers, paddled up a river that the local peoples called Netul, now called the Lewis and Clark River.Â On December 5, the expedition established Fort Clatsop at a site on the riverbank that had been selected by Lewis.Â 

Today

Now the river is named after Lewis and Clark, but Netul Landing pays homage to the former name and is an excellent place to launch your kayak or canoe for a paddle trip. Bring your non-motorized boat or sign up for aÂ ranger guided canoe and kayak tripÂ during the summer months.

The launch is part of the Lewis and Clark Columbia River Water Trail, a 146-mile stretch of water that follows the explorers' route on the Lower Columbia River from Bonneville Dam to the Pacific Ocean, near Ilwaco, Wash. For more detailed information go to theLower Columbia River Water Trail website.

Netul Landing also marks one end of the new Lewis and Clark River Trail. The river trail is a 1.5-mile gentle walk along the river to Fort Clatsop. Visitors may park in the parking area and follow the trail to the Fort Clatsop Visitor Center, where they will learn about the areaâs history. At the landing and along the trail, interpretive panels are installed that discuss Lewis and Clarkâs time here. Visitor's can also connectÂ with the Fort to Sea trail and trace the Corps' trip to Sunset Beach.

Visitors are required to pay an entrance fee to Lewis and Clark National Historical Park, which can be paid at the visitor center. For more information, call the park at (503) 861-2471 or check out ourÂ mapÂ of the area.


IF YOU GO

From Astoria, head south on U.S. Highway 101 and follow the signs to Fort Clatsop. Drive 1.5 miles past the entrance to the fort to Netul Landing. From Seaside, head north on U.S. 101 and follow the signs.Â 
Â
audioDescription: Replicas of canoes like those used by Lewis and Clark and the native people are situated at the treelined shore of the Columbia River, marking the location where visitors may put their boats into the water. The trailhead to the Netul River Trail is also located here.

title: North Netul Picnic Shelter

images.altText: An L shaped open air plank picnic shelter, interpretive signs both inside and outside.
images.title: North Netul Picnic Shelter
images.caption: The picnic shelter at North Netul Landing is an open air interpretive site.

relatedParks.fullName: Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lewis and Clark

bodyText:
A spot to rest your legs and read on the local history.

Whether you're just setting out on one of our many trails or looking for a place to read more on the history of this area you'll find the shelter at North Netul to fit your needs. With multiple picnic tables, an open air plank shelter, and interpretive signs both inside and around the shelter that deal with the Clatsops, Lewis and Clark, the logging industry, and bioswales. Take a breather and enjoy the tidal waters of the Netul River.

This is stop 8 on the Restoring Nature Audio tour.
audioDescription: An L shaped open air structure sits upon concrete slabs that make up a bulkhead. The Netul River sits opposite of the entrance to the structure. The structure has wooden slats that make up the sides of it, allowing air to flow through the bottom and top while the middle is made of the slats. The middle slats are dotted with informative signs, each of which can be accessed through this app to read the contents to you. Above, the blue metal roof protects the shelter. Looking upwards while inside the shelter towards the roof will show many bird nests and, on occasion, a roosting bat.

title: Parade Grounds of Fort Clatsop

images.altText: A 48 foot long by 20 foot wide open space in the middle of Fort Clatsop with a flagpole.
images.title: Parade Grounds of Fort Clatsop
images.caption: Drills, meetings, and more would be conducted in the parade grounds.

relatedParks.fullName: Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lewis and Clark

bodyText: The Parade Grounds are the middle area of the fort where military drills, morning meetings, and possibly the raising and lowering of the American flag took place. The original fort wouldn't have had the luxury of woodchips to protect from muddy conditions; the rain combined with the inward slanting roofs would have made the parade ground very messy if boards or gutters were not placed or made.
audioDescription: Measuring 48 feet long by 20 feet wide, this middle area has the enlisted mens rooms on the left side and the higher ups rooms on the right side. At the back of the parade grounds a tall flagpole with a 15 star 15 stripe flag flying stands and behind that the water-gate. The back gate leads out on a trail into the woods.

title: Salt Cairn Replica

images.altText: Various sized round stones connected to form a short arch support 5 kettles on top with wood inside
images.title: Salt Cairn Replica
images.caption: The replica of the Salt Cairn shows what was used to boil ocean water to make salt.

relatedParks.fullName: Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lewis and Clark

tags: Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
bodyText:
Built at what's reportedly the exact spot as the original camp site, this replica salt cairn shows what the Corps of Discoveries Saltmakers would have used as they boiled ocean water for much needed salt.Â Five men traveled to this beach site, built the camp and set five kettles to boiling, 24 hours a day, to produce salt. According to their records, they set out from Fort Clatsop on Dec. 28, 1805, and left the camp Feb. 20, 1806, with 3 Â½ bushels or about 28 gallons of "Excellent, fine, strong & white" salt.

Salt was used not only as an important preservative for meat that would begin to spoil within hours of killing it in the Pacific Northwest's winter weather, but also used in the tanning process to help create buckskin clothing for the expedition members.

Far from the water's edge, this replica stands as a show of how far the beach has extended westward, and shows the growth of the city that surrounds it.

You can find more information about the Salt Works on the official Salt Works page.
audioDescription: On the middle of a concrete slab, surrounded by raised concrete walls and a wrought iron fence, is a two foot tall arch of various sized round stones cobbled together with a one foot tall tunnel passing through the middle. In the tunnel dry cut firewood is stored while five kettles sit atop the salt cairn.

title: Salt Works, Oregon
listingDescription: Several members of the Lewis and Clark Expedition spent the winter at a Clatsop-Nehalem Village near here, boiling ocean water to make salt for the return journey.

images.altText: Five metal kettles sit on top of a rock half-cylinder structure, with a hollowed area underneath.
images.title: The Salt Works
images.caption: Salt work replica as pictured in 2021.

relatedParks.fullName: Lewis & Clark National Historic Trail
relatedParks.name: Lewis & Clark

relatedParks.fullName: Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lewis and Clark

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
Meriwether Lewis and William Clarkâs party ran out of salt on their journey west.Â Â 

Salt was crucial in preserving meat for the lean winter months.Â Plus, it made food taste better. Clark said he didnât mind going without salt, but Lewis found unsalted food bland.Â Â 

They decided to spend the winter near the Pacific Ocean so that they could make salt by boiling ocean water.Â 

Privates Joseph Field, William Bratton, and George Gibson led the salt-making initiative.Â They chose a spot on the coast, near a Clatsop-Nehalem village (in present-day Seaside, Oregon). It was only a few days journey to walk from Fort Clatsop to the salt works.Â 

Field, Bratton, and Gibson befriended the people in the Clatsop-Nehalem village, who âhad been verry kind and attentive to them.âÂ Some may have even allowed Field, Bratton, and Gibson to stay in their wooden houses, which would have been better shelter from the wet winds than canvas tents.Â The people of the village also helped feed the salt makers, selling them whale blubber to eat.Â Â 

They probably played games, such as one that many people in the area played that involved holding a small item in your hand while others guessed which hand it was in.Â Maybe they taught each other songs, even if they couldnât understand each otherâs languages.Â Â 

By the end of the winter, they had made some twenty gallons of salt (by Lewisâs count), plenty to sustain them during the journey home.Â Â 

About this article: This article is part of a series called âPivotal Places: Stories from the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail.â

title: South Slough Foot Bridge

images.altText: A brown metal bridge extends over a still river, the reflection of the bridge visible in the water
images.title: South Slough Foot Bridge
images.caption: A serene stillness between the meetup of two bodies of water can lead to reflections from the water.

relatedParks.fullName: Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lewis and Clark

bodyText:
Where Colewart Creek enters the Netul River there is a beautiful calm to the area. Places like these, off of the main Netul River, are used by numerous species of fish in order to rest their weary fins and remain safe from predators such as the numerous Great Blue Heron and Bald Eagles that call the Netul River home.Â Â 

While birds and fish are common sites here, as you cross the bridge you may be lucky enough to see River Otter or some of the other species that call this land home.

This location serves as stops 5-7 on the Restoring Nature Audio Tour.
audioDescription: At approximately 50 feet long by 8 feet wide, the long brown metal bridge crosses over a body of water surrounded by grasses, plants, and occasionally birds, otters, and fish too. To the left of the bridge the Netul River flows, large wooden pilings dot the river. To the right of the bridge is a culvert and Fort Clatsop Road.

title: Sunset Beach State Recreation Site
listingDescription: Sunset Beach State Recreation Site marks the west trailhead of the historic Fort-to-Sea Trail, which is a 6.5 mile route that recreates the experience of Lewis and Clark and the Corps of Discovery as they traveled between Fort Clatsop and the Pacific Ocean during the winter of 1805-6. Sunset Beach State Recreation Site is 120-acres, and provides visitors with direct access to the Pacific Ocean.

images.altText: The sandy slope of a dune leading to the ocean with a blue sky in the background.
images.title: Sunset Beach
images.caption: Sunset Beach State Recreation Site

tags: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail
Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
bodyText:
Sunset Beach State Recreation Site is located southwest of Astoria, Oregon, and provides visitors with direct access to the Pacific Ocean. On a clear day visitors can enjoy expansive views north towards Cape Disappointment State Park, and south towards Ecola State Park.Â 

The recreation site is 120-acres, and marks the west trailhead of the historic Fort-to-Sea Trail. This trail is 6.5 miles long one-way, and recreates the experience of Lewis and Clark and the Corps of Discovery as they traveled between Fort Clatsop and the Pacific Ocean during the winter of 1805-6.Â 

For additional information please go to Sunset Beach State Recreation Site's website.Â 



Â

title: The Enlisted Men's Rooms of Fort Clatsop

images.altText: Three doorways enter into dark rooms of a 50 foot long log fort
images.title: The Enlisted Men's Rooms
images.caption: Three huts side by side made up the rooms of the Enlisted Men

relatedParks.fullName: Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lewis and Clark

bodyText:
The three rooms for the enlisted men of the Lewis and Clark expedition were likely divided between each of the three squads. The first had seven men, the second nine, and the third seven. While the rooms are small it is unlikely that they were often packed full all at the same time. After all this was a working fort, the men were always busy with one task or another. Those tasks often included hunting, guard duty, gathering firewood, repairs and construction, smithing, or for a small crew, making salt down at the salt works in modern day Seaside.Â 

Of these rooms the middle was notably the largest on the floorplans and likely would have belonged to the largest squad. It is told through the passed down oral history of the local Clatsop nation that the room also had a large tree strump in the middle, and has earned the nickname of simply "The Stump Room."
audioDescription: Constructed entirely of wooden logs with a cedar plank roof, the three enlisted men's rooms total a width of 50 feet and make up the left wall of Fort Clatsop. It is approximately fifteen feet tall at its highest with inward sloping roof tops. The back of each room has a firepit that leads to a wooden vent opening at the top of each fort room. Inside each room are 8 wooden bunkbeds, a wooden table, and a wooden loft at the top covered in boxes, skulls, and carrying crates. In the summer time regimental uniforms, tools, flintlock muskets, and more can be found. If you are curious to find out what is currently in the rooms, as they rotate seasonally, please ask a park ranger for assistance.

images.title: Lewis & Clark Salt Works
images.caption: The site of the Lewis and Clark Salt Works

relatedParks.fullName: Lewis & Clark National Historic Trail
relatedParks.name: Lewis & Clark

relatedParks.fullName: Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lewis and Clark

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
bodyText:
History

Much of the Corps' stay on the North Coast was spent securing sustenance for the winter and provisions for the trip home.Â On December 28, 1805, the Lewis & Clark Expedition sent out a detachment of five men in search of a good place to make salt. The expedition, which had been wintering at Fort Clatsop, had run out and were in desperate need of more. Salt was important for meat preservation and thus for the crewâs survival on the trip back home. The rivers near the fort werenât salty enough, and so a better place had to be found. The men found an ideal spot on the Pacific Ocean approximately 15 miles from Fort Clatsop where they set up the salt processing camp.

Making salt required a bit of planning and a lot of work. Sea water had to be collected and allowed to sit till the sand sank to the bottom. Then the men had to collect a large supply of firewood and build a stone furnace, on top of which they placed five kettles that had to boil 24 hours a day to produce the salt. Captain William Clark and few additional men joined the others at the salt works a little over a week later on January 9, arriving in the early afternoon. The group stayed at the salt works until February 20, when they left with 3.5 bushels (about 28 gallons) of âExcellent, fine, strong & whiteâ salt.

Â 

Today

Today, visitors can see the site believed to be the expeditionâs salt works. It was identified by a rock cairn and the testimony of Jenny Michel, born in 1816 to a Clatsop man who had pointed the place out to her when she was a child. According to her father, this was the place he had seen white men boiling water.

The site is located on the Promenade. At the intersection of US Highway 101 and Avenue G, turn west to Beach Drive, then left to Lewis and Clark Way. Park where available without blocking private driveways. Walk west on Lewis and Clark Way to the Salt Cairn.


Â
audioDescription: Nestled between buildings on the Promenade, the salt works cairn sits inside a small stone courtyard surrounded by a brick and wrought iron fence. A plaque tells of the Lewis and Clark Expedition's time here at the site, and how Jenny Michel, born in 1816 and whose father remembered the white men, identified this site for the Oregon Historical Society in 1900, five years before her death.

title: The Officers and Civilians Rooms of Fort Clatsop

images.altText: A row of rooms made of stacked logs and a large wooden chimney
images.title: The Officers Quarters
images.caption: The officers and civilians rooms as seen from the parade grounds.

relatedParks.fullName: Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lewis and Clark

bodyText:
According to the floorplans of Fort Clatsop, the rooms for officers and civilians are on the right side after entering the main gate.

The first room on the right belonged to the civilian interpreter Toussaint Charbonneau and his Wife Sacagawea as well as their son, who turns one year old here, Jean Baptiste Charbonneau. The room to its left was the captains quarters for Lewis and Clark. The third room down was known as the Orderly Room and may have been for the three sergents and perhaps the other civilian Geourge Droulliard. It is unknown if Captain Clark's enslaved man, York, would have stayed in the captains or sergeants room. The final room on this side was the storage room for meat, tools, trade goods, and the few other supplies they had left. It was the duty of the sergeants to ensure no one got into the storage room or bothered the captains without due reason.
audioDescription: Constructed entirely of wooden logs with a cedar plank roof, the four rooms total a width of 50 feet and make up the right wall of Fort Clatsop. It is approximately fifteen feet tall at its highest with inward sloping roof tops. The back of each room has a firepit that leads to a wooden vent opening at the top of each fort room, except the middle room which has a twenty-foot tall wooden chimney. Inside the family room a single large bed fills near half of the room space, a small wooden chair next to it. Other coats, a fur hide mattress, and a wool blanket may be present in the room on a seasonal basis. Inside the captains room two beds line the right-side of the room while a large table, two chairs, two desks, and a fireplace and mantle line the left side of the room. Seasonally the desks may be decorated with a map, quill pens, ink wells, furs, horns, antlers, plant presses, and more. The sergents room has two bunk beds, four beds in total, on the right side of the room and a small table in the back left with a single chair. The back room has a bottom layer of woodchips that support multiple wooden crates and barrels. Skulls, antlers, and leather hides rest on top of the barrels and crates or hang from wooden support beams. Large pots and kettles are scattered around the room. If you are curious to find out what is currently in the rooms, as they rotate seasonally, please ask a park ranger for assistance.

title: The Sentinel Box at Fort Clatsop

images.altText: A small wooden shack pressed against the side of Fort Clatop about 6' tall and 3' wide.
images.title: Fort Clatsop Sentinel Box
images.caption: This small wooden shack provided needed protection from the weather.

relatedParks.fullName: Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lewis and Clark

bodyText: As a military expedition it was required that a guard was always on duty, unfortunately the very wet winters we experience make that a miserable experience. Because of the constant rain a sentry box was constructed to help shelter the guard, them being able to stand inside and keep their gun and gunpowder from getting wet.
audioDescription: A small wooden shack about 6 and a half feet tall and two and a half feet wide, a sloped roof of cedar planks stops rain from falling into the shack.

title: The Vote at Station Camp
listingDescription: On November 24, 1805, members of the Lewis and Clark Expedition voted on where to spend the winter. The opinions of Sacagawea (an Indigenous woman) and York (a Black man enslaved by William Clark) were recorded along with those of the other crew members.

images.altText: Wooden canoe in grassy field.
images.title: Station Camp
images.caption: This sculpture of a Chinookan canoe is located at the site of Middle Camp, a Chinookan trading place

relatedParks.fullName: Lewis & Clark National Historic Trail
relatedParks.name: Lewis & Clark

relatedParks.fullName: Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lewis and Clark

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
After reaching the Pacific Ocean, it was time to decide where to spend the winter. William Clark polled everyone on November 24, 1805, and tallied their votes in his journal.Â Â 

Clark recorded the vote of York, a Black man he enslaved. This was decades before Black men had the right to vote in the United States.Â Several years after the Lewis and Clark Expedition, York asked for his freedom. Clark denied his request. How meaningful was Yorkâs vote, if he still was not free?Â 

Clark also asked Sacagaweaâs opinion on where to stay over the winter. Her vote was not tallied, but Clark made a note that she wanted to stay somewhere with lots of wapato, to make sure they had enough food for the winter.Â The group decision did not heed her concerns, but her point played out: they spent much of the winter trading with the Clatsop for wapato and other food. And their health suffered at times when they had only dried salmon or spoiled elk meat to eat.Â 

Ultimately, Lewis and Clarkâs party decided to stay south of the Columbia River, where the Clatsop people lived and where there would be easy access to the ocean. The hunting would be good there, it was close to the ocean for salt-making, and they hoped the rain wouldnât be as bad.Â 

Sacagawea voicing her opinion in 1805 gained more attention a century later. The womenâs suffrage movement used Sacagaweaâs input at Station Camp as a symbol of why women deserved the right to vote.Â That right came at the national level in 1920 with the passage of the Nineteenth Amendment. However, barriers to suffrage still existed for people of color, including Indigenous women, until well into the twentieth century.

Sacagawea and York gave their opinions to the White men leading the expeditionâan expedition that neither of them freely chose to join. But did their votes make a lasting difference for Black people, Indigenous people, or women?Â Â 

About this article: This article is part of a series called âPivotal Places: Stories from the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail.â
audioDescription: Flat, open area next to the river, with forested hills emerging immediately behind it. Wide expanse of river visible. There is a parking lot next to a wooden church, canoe sculptures, and interpretive trail.

quickFacts.value: The members of the Lewis and Clark Expedition stopped here in November 1805 to vote on where to spend the winter. All members of the party gave their opinion on where they wanted to stay, including York (a Black man enslaved by William Clark) and Sacagawea (an Indigenous woman).
